claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination significantly expands the repertoire of tumor-specific peptides presented on MHC-I molecules, making the tumor more visible to the immune system.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: The sensitization effect relies on Type I interferon signaling, which is induced by the intratumoral mRNA delivery and is necessary for the observed benefit.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect, confirming the importance of the mRNA payload and not just the delivery vehicle.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccination and anti-PD-L1 therapy significantly increases anti-tumor efficacy, evidenced by increased CD8+ T-cell infiltration and improved control.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models, indicating the necessity of the combination.

claims.claim: A retrospective analysis suggests that metastatic cancer patients who received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination show improved overall survival when subsequently treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely and limits the strength of the conclusion.
